Posts.Content: Hi Ladies  I don't want to be a Jonah but you ate on for a long hard slog The only way  I have been able to come to terms with all the after effects is to lower my expectations of when I might get 'back to normal ' I had originally expected to feel better after  a few months.  My target days came and went and I grew more frightened that I hadn't noticeably improved  I got to the point where I said 'f*** this' I'm making myself ill by setting my expectations too high I gave myself a good talking to  and told myself not to expect a significant improvement for at least another year and if they can't handle it the that's tough. I am recovering from cancer you know I think I will probably make this target which fills me with hope amd confidence.  I also keep a personal diary of my progress and over the last 6 months  I cam see a steady  improvement  Good luck

Posts.Content: Hi Caroline  I can't offer any advice on your specific situation as mine was throat cancer but let me give you some reassurance  Firstly rhe way you are feeling is absolutely normal. There is a lot written about the effects of chemo and radiotherapy but very little about the psychological aftershock  I was doing SO well and then after 3 months out of the blue I felt like I had been hit by a truck  Couldn't eat,  sleep, got really emotional.  In the end I went to my doctor who said I was suffering post operative stress disorder and gave me prozac and sleeping pills My hospital were brilliant but I was very aware they were working to a timetable and yes there were more concerned about burning from the rads and I didn't get my scan till 5 months after rads finished so don't take it personally.  On my own case I am finding post treatment far more difficult 5han the actual treatment. Sorry to be a Jonah  The interesting thing is once treated you are not considered urgent . The critical thing from the hospitals view is that tbey get those awaiting treatment are processed first and therefore are their priority. Sorry to be that cynical but from the hospitals point of view you are now low priority, which I suppose is a slight reassurance  Oncologists hardly if ever use the word CURE so the fact they have is very encouraging  Most people will advise you not to Google your condition but I wanted to be forewarned and asked extremely probing questions about my condition which I thonk shocked the oncologist and they kinda sat up and took notice of me I wish you the very best. The next bit is very lonely. Keep going to  the counselling, this is now a psychological battle for you and the counsellors REALLY helped me  Good luck

Posts.Content: Hi DiAbbott  First of  all the legal bit Cancer is seen as a disability and to even try and 'remove' somebody because they have had time off for treatment or convalescening is an act of discrimination and your company can be prosecuted,  so rest East The 2nd thing to  ask is do you REALLY want to  work with such a bunch of arseholes  However, onot better things I had surgery chemo, cisplatin  and 35 rads . Let me tell you it is a bitch but you can do it. Lots and lots of painkillers.  As tough as it was the really tough bit for me is post treatment.  I am 5 months out of radio and have suffered, elation, depression,  hate , anger., despair, insomnia, etc etc and at the flick of a switch  A trip to  my doctor and a bucketfulof prozac has helped enormously.  My doctor said I was suffering post operative stress disorder and it was very very common.  So rest assured you are normal It is tough but doable. I was told by my oncologist not to expect a significant improvement fir at least  a year.  These things take time particular the psychological aftershock  Good luck

Posts.Content: Hi Maria First of all I'm so glad you won your battle with cancer  Secondly I don't know if you know Newtons Law of Relativity.  It is extremely useful when dealing with difficult people  Newton said that for every action there is an equal an opposite reaction  Applied to people, particularly when extreme emotions are involved, it works like this The Harder you try and build bridges with people the more they back off Try this.  You back off them. Don't call them for a few weeks. Let them come to you, on your terms and see what happens  It's a basic animal instinct  We had a very haughty Siamese cat. The more I tried to make a fuss of her the more she turned her nose up at me so I stopped trying to make her like me. After a few weeks I was sitting watching the TV, in she walked and jumped on my lap and starting purring Good luck

Posts.Content: Dreamthief Hiya, 'Early' can mean several things like finding it within 4 months of a previous clear mammogram or while looking for something else unrelated, but in the true sense of their wording for BC it would be DCIS or LCIS (ductal or lobular in situ) it doesn't become classed as invasive while it is contained (in situ)  Early can also refer to finding a pre-cancerous condition. Unless tissue samples from the path lab upgrades them these are at first classed as grade zero. Where the cells 'break out through the wall where it was contained  it then becomes invasive, sounds harsh but may only mean a few cells have settled in areas close to the original cluster - terms like like vascular invasion or some cells found trapped in the nearest lymph nodes. Early can also be used where the tumour size is small, but as we all know even small tumours can be found to be a higher grade 2 or 3, so this is a bit of a misconception. it is a very grey area and 'early' is a loosely used term (even by us here) and personally I don't think it counts for much.  Jackie was DCIS (grade zero remember ?) with a fairly small 8mm tumour just behind the nipple. Post surgery pathology confirmed it was in fact Grade 3 ER+  &  PR+  and also HER2+ so she had MX, 6 x chemo, 18 x  Herceptin and 15 x rads - So DCIS doesn't count for much until the final results are in Think I've just muddied the water a bit,  G n' J How long is piece of string?  It really is that ambiguous  My tumour was stage one but had spread to the lymph nodes.  By size it was minute but was now spreading aggressively I asked my  ONC had long I had had it. He shrugged is shoulders and siad' who can tell, 2 months or 30 years it's so difficult  to tell' Generally speaking rhough most people refer  to 'catching it early'  as.a small tumor in situ under  2cm in diameter and the cancer has not spread to distant parts of the body. The m2dical term being metastatic  Hope that helps
